title: Hello Afrika!: Speech Commands in Kinyarwanda
author: George Igwegbe (Carnegie Mellon University, Africa), Martins Awojide (Carnegie Mellon University, Africa), Mboh Bless (Carnegie Mellon University, Africa), Nirel Kadzo (Carnegie Mellon University, Africa), ...
relevance_why: This project addresses speech recognition in Kinyarwanda, potentially impacting the field of audio processing and language modeling, which aligns with Haohe's interests in audio generation and manipulation.
background: Developing a speech command model for the Kinyarwanda language to enable voice-activated functionalities in smart devices.
contribution: This paper introduces a speech command model for Kinyarwanda to solve the lack of speech recognition technologies for African languages, achieving deployment across multiple devices.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing models focus on popular languages, neglecting African languages with limited datasets.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work employs a custom speech command corpus and utilizes a combination of Convolutional Neural Networks and Long Short-Term Memory models to optimize keyword detection.

key_innovation: The project establishes a dedicated corpus and model for Kinyarwanda, enabling voice control functionalities in native languages, which is unprecedented for this linguistic group.
real_world_impact: The successful implementation can significantly enhance the usability of smart devices for native Kinyarwanda speakers, particularly benefiting individuals with disabilities.
limitations: The model's performance varied significantly across datasets, indicating challenges in dataset diversity and possible overfitting.

new_terms.keyword spotting: **Keyword spotting** refers to the ability of a system to recognize predefined words or phrases from audio input.
new_terms.Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM): **Long Short-Term Memory** is a type of recurrent neural network architecture capable of learning long-term dependencies, commonly used in sequence prediction tasks.

open_sourcing: Code and guidance are available on GitHub: https://github.com/gigwegbe/hello_afrika_speech_commands
